Award.AwardTitle: NSF/CBMS Regional Conference in the Mathematical Sciences -- Mathematical Methods of Computed Tomography
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support an NSF/CMBS regional conference to be held at the University of Texas at Arlington in the summer of 2012 on the topic of mathematical methods of computed tomography. The principal speaker will be Professor Peter Kuchment from Texas A&M University. This award will support 30 participants at different stages of their careers. Computed tomography techniques used for medical imaging aim to recover the internal distribution of various important tissue parameters such as density, water content, oxygenation, hemoglobin content, electrical conductivity, optical properties, and mechanical properties. These are parameters are used by medical practitioners for diagnosis of many types of conditions.

The conference will survey mathematical techniques, results, and open problems in the actively developing and important field of computed tomography, aiming to encourage both established and more junior mathematicians to begin research in this field. The speaker will address both classical tomographic modalities, such as x-ray computed tomography, single photon emission computed tomography, positron emission tomography, magnetic resonance imaging, electrical impedance tomography, ultrasound tomography, and optical tomography, and novel hybrid methods currently being developed, such as thermoacoustic and photoacoustic tomography, magnetic resonance electrical impedance tomography, acousto-electric tomography, acousto-optical tomography, and magnetic resonance elastography.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An NSF-CBMS Conference on Mathematical Methods of Computed Tomography during May 29-June 2, 2012 was organized in the Department of Mathematics at the University of Texas at Arlington. This conference featured Prof. Peter Kuchment of Texas A&M University as the distinguished lecturer who delivered ten lectures in the field of computed tomography. The objectives were to bring established researchers and newcomers together to an environment where the participants would interact with each other and also with the principal lecturer, to promote interdisciplinary work and collaborations, to include women and minorities in the research activities, to stimulate the regional research activity in an atmosphere conducive to establishing long term collaborations, to provide an interdisciplinary environment where mathematicians and researchers from other areas interact, to have the principal lecturer prepare an expository monograph serving a much wider audience, to contribute to national research activity in an important area, and to enhance the research atmosphere at the University of Texas at Arlington as well as at other institutions in the Dallas-Fort Worth metroplex area and in the region.

The goal of computed tomography is to recover the interior structure of a nontransparent body by using external measurements. One of the major applications of tomographic methods is in medical diagnostic imaging. Contemporary classical as well as newly developed modern techniques strive to recover the internal distribution of various tissue parameters such as density, water content, oxygenation, hemoglobin content, electrical conductivity, optical properties (absorption and scattering coefficients), and mechanical properties (e.g., stiffness). Such parameters play crucial roles in medical diagnostics, in particular, of early detection of cancer and pulmonary edema (fluid build up in lungs).

Prof. Kuchment gave two talks each morning of the conference with a break between the talks. In the afternoon we had sessions to elaborate on the morning lectures and to discuss open problems. Prof. Kuchment will prepare by June 2, 2013 an expository monograph based on his lectures, which will be published by SIAM (Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics). The lectures covered  all the major ideas and results in the field, provided a deeper understanding of the main open problems, and outlined the current directions in the field. The field of computed tomography is an interdisciplinary area, and the mathematical aspects of the conference had direct relevance in physics and engineering, especially in biomedical engineering. The participants were also exposed to interdisciplinary aspects of computed tomography. Some participants were already in interdisciplinary areas at the cross section of mathematics, physics, and engineering, and they benefited from the conference.

There were 54 participants at the conference, including both established researchers and interested qualified newcomers. The participants included postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and traditionally underrepresented groups. The conference allowed participants to interact with each other and also with the principal lecturer, promoted interdisciplinary work and collaborations, encouraged establishing long term collaborations. The conference contributed to national research activity in the important area of computed tomography, enhanced the research atmosphere at University of Texas at Arlington as well as at other institutions in the Dallas-Fort Worth metroplex area and in the region.
